penguin.headline: Emperor (Aptenodytes forsteri)
penguin.summary: The Emperor penguin is truly the supreme and most dignified of all penguins, as it towers above the rest at an amazing 115 cm.

penguin.headline: King (Aptenodytes patagonica patagonica)
penguin.summary: Despite the name, King penguins are not the giants of all penguins; those are the Emperor penguins.

penguin.headline: Fiordland (Eudyptes pachyrhynchus)
penguin.summary: The Fiordland penguin is easily confused with the Snares Island penguin and the Erect-crested penguin.

penguin.headline: Macaroni (Eudyptes chysolophus)
penguin.summary: Macaroni penguins are easily identified from the other crested penguins: their crests are bright orange and form on the centerline of the dorsal head and point outwardly, slightly posteriorly.

penguin.headline: Rockhopper (Eudyptes crestatus)
penguin.summary: Rockhoppers are often considered the favorites of many people.

penguin.headline: Snares Island (Eudyptes robutsus)
penguin.summary: It's easy to confuse the Snares Island penguins with some of the other crested penguins, especially while they're swimming.

penguin.headline: Little-blue (Eudyptula albosignata)
penguin.summary: The Little-blue penguins have many local and informal names.

penguin.headline: Yellow-eyed (Megadyptes antipodes)
penguin.summary: The Yellow-eyed penguins are the sole members of the genus Megadyptes. They are a beautiful bird that is easily recognized given their profuse yellow coloring of their heads and their yellow irises.
